text: James, a servant of God and of the Lord Jesus Christ, to the twelve tribes which are in the Dispersion: Greetings.
speaker: Narrator

text: Count it all joy, my brothers, when you fall into various temptations,
speaker: Narrator

text: knowing that the testing of your faith produces endurance.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let endurance have its perfect work, that you may be perfect and complete, lacking in nothing.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if any of you lacks wisdom, let him ask of God, who gives to all liberally and without reproach, and it will be given to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: But let him ask in faith, without any doubting, for he who doubts is like a wave of the sea, driven by the wind and tossed.
speaker: Narrator

text: For that man shouldn’t think that he will receive anything from the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: He is a double-minded man, unstable in all his ways.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let the brother in humble circumstances glory in his high position;
speaker: Narrator

text: and the rich, in that he is made humble, because like the flower in the grass, he will pass away.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the sun arises with the scorching wind and withers the grass; and the flower in it falls, and the beauty of its appearance perishes. So the rich man will also fade away in his pursuits.
speaker: Narrator

text: Blessed is a person who endures temptation, for when he has been approved, he will receive the crown of life which the Lord promised to those who love him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let no man say when he is tempted, “I am tempted by God,” for God can’t be tempted by evil, and he himself tempts no one.
speaker: Narrator

text: But each one is tempted when he is drawn away by his own lust and enticed.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the lust, when it has conceived, bears sin. The sin, when it is full grown, produces death.
speaker: Narrator

text: Don’t be deceived, my beloved brothers.
speaker: Narrator

text: Every good gift and every perfect gift is from above, coming down from the Father of lights, with whom can be no variation nor turning shadow.
speaker: Narrator

text: Of his own will he gave birth to us by the word of truth, that we should be a kind of first fruits of his creatures.
speaker: Narrator

text: So, then, my beloved brothers, let every man be swift to hear, slow to speak, and slow to anger;
speaker: Narrator

text: for the anger of man doesn’t produce the righteousness of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore, putting away all filthiness and overflowing of wickedness, receive with humility the implanted word, which is able to save your souls.
speaker: Narrator

text: But be doers of the word, and not only hearers, deluding your own selves.
speaker: Narrator

text: For if anyone is a hearer of the word and not a doer, he is like a man looking at his natural face in a mirror;
speaker: Narrator

text: for he sees himself, and goes away, and immediately forgets what kind of man he was.
speaker: Narrator

text: But he who looks into the perfect law of freedom and continues, not being a hearer who forgets but a doer of the work, this man will be blessed in what he does.
speaker: Narrator

text: If anyone among you thinks himself to be religious while he doesn’t bridle his tongue, but deceives his heart, this man’s religion is worthless.
speaker: Narrator

text: Pure religion and undefiled before our God and Father is this: to visit the fatherless and widows in their affliction, and to keep oneself unstained by the world.
speaker: Narrator

text: My brothers, don’t hold the faith of our glorious Lord Jesus Christ with partiality.
speaker: Narrator

text: For if a man with a gold ring, in fine clothing, comes into your synagogue, and a poor man in filthy clothing also comes in,
speaker: Narrator

text: and you pay special attention to him who wears the fine clothing and say, “Sit here in a good place;” and you tell the poor man, “Stand there,” or “Sit by my footstool”
speaker: Narrator

text: haven’t you shown partiality among yourselves, and become judges with evil thoughts?
speaker: Narrator

text: Listen, my beloved brothers. Didn’t God choose those who are poor in this world to be rich in faith and heirs of the Kingdom which he promised to those who love him?
speaker: Narrator

text: But you have dishonored the poor man. Don’t the rich oppress you and personally drag you before the courts?
speaker: Narrator

text: Don’t they blaspheme the honorable name by which you are called?
speaker: Narrator

text: However, if you fulfill the royal law according to the Scripture, “You shall love your neighbor as yourself,” you do well.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if you show partiality, you commit sin, being convicted by the law as transgressors.
speaker: Narrator

text: For whoever keeps the whole law, and yet stumbles in one point, he has become guilty of all.
speaker: Narrator

text: For he who said, “Do not commit adultery,” also said, “Do not commit murder.” Now if you do not commit adultery but do murder, you have become a transgressor of the law.
speaker: Narrator

text: So speak and so do as men who are to be judged by the law of freedom.
speaker: Narrator

text: For judgment is without mercy to him who has shown no mercy. Mercy triumphs over judgment.
speaker: Narrator

text: What good is it, my brothers, if a man says he has faith, but has no works? Can faith save him?
speaker: Narrator

text: And if a brother or sister is naked and in lack of daily food,
speaker: Narrator

text: and one of you tells them, “Go in peace. Be warmed and filled;” yet you didn’t give them the things the body needs, what good is it?
speaker: Narrator

text: Even so faith, if it has no works, is dead in itself.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yes, a man will say, “You have faith, and I have works.” Show me your faith without works, and I will show you my faith by my works.
speaker: Narrator

text: You believe that God is one. You do well. The demons also believe—and shudder.
speaker: Narrator

text: But do you want to know, vain man, that faith apart from works is dead?
speaker: Narrator

text: Wasn’t Abraham our father justified by works, in that he offered up Isaac his son on the altar?
speaker: Narrator

text: You see that faith worked with his works, and by works faith was perfected.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the Scripture was fulfilled which says, “Abraham believed God, and it was accounted to him as righteousness,” and he was called the friend of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: You see then that by works a man is justified, and not only by faith.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the same way, wasn’t Rahab the prostitute also justified by works when she received the messengers and sent them out another way?
speaker: Narrator

text: For as the body apart from the spirit is dead, even so faith apart from works is dead.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let not many of you be teachers, my brothers, knowing that we will receive heavier judgment.
speaker: Narrator

text: For we all stumble in many things. Anyone who doesn’t stumble in word is a perfect person, able to bridle the whole body also.
speaker: Narrator

text: Indeed, we put bits into the horses’ mouths so that they may obey us, and we guide their whole body.
speaker: Narrator

text: Behold, the ships also, though they are so big and are driven by fierce winds, are yet guided by a very small rudder, wherever the pilot desires.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the tongue is also a little member, and boasts great things. See how a small fire can spread to a large forest!
speaker: Narrator

text: And the tongue is a fire. The world of iniquity among our members is the tongue, which defiles the whole body, and sets on fire the course of nature, and is set on fire by Gehenna.
speaker: Narrator

text: For every kind of animal, bird, creeping thing, and sea creature is tamed, and has been tamed by mankind;
speaker: Narrator

text: but nobody can tame the tongue. It is a restless evil, full of deadly poison.
speaker: Narrator

text: With it we bless our God and Father, and with it we curse men who are made in the image of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Out of the same mouth comes blessing and cursing. My brothers, these things ought not to be so.
speaker: Narrator

text: Does a spring send out from the same opening fresh and bitter water?
speaker: Narrator

text: Can a fig tree, my brothers, yield olives, or a vine figs? Thus no spring yields both salt water and fresh water.
speaker: Narrator

text: Who is wise and understanding among you? Let him show by his good conduct that his deeds are done in gentleness of wisdom.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if you have bitter jealousy and selfish ambition in your heart, don’t boast and don’t lie against the truth.
speaker: Narrator

text: This wisdom is not that which comes down from above, but is earthly, sensual, and demonic.
speaker: Narrator

text: For where jealousy and selfish ambition are, there is confusion and every evil deed.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the wisdom that is from above is first pure, then peaceful, gentle, reasonable, full of mercy and good fruits, without partiality, and without hypocrisy.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the fruit of righteousness is sown in peace by those who make peace.
speaker: Narrator

text: Where do wars and fightings among you come from? Don’t they come from your pleasures that war in your members?
speaker: Narrator

text: You lust, and don’t have. You murder and covet, and can’t obtain. You fight and make war. You don’t have, because you don’t ask.
speaker: Narrator

text: You ask, and don’t receive, because you ask with wrong motives, so that you may spend it on your pleasures.
speaker: Narrator

text: You adulterers and adulteresses, don’t you know that friendship with the world is hostility toward God? Whoever therefore wants to be a friend of the world makes himself an enemy of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Or do you think that the Scripture says in vain, “The Spirit who lives in us yearns jealously”?
speaker: Narrator

text: But he gives more grace. Therefore it says, “God resists the proud, but gives grace to the humble.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Be subject therefore to God. Resist the devil, and he will flee from you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Draw near to God, and he will draw near to you. Cleanse your hands, you sinners. Purify your hearts, you double-minded.
speaker: Narrator

text: Lament, mourn, and weep. Let your laughter be turned to mourning and your joy to gloom.
speaker: Narrator

text: Humble yourselves in the sight of the Lord, and he will exalt you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Don’t speak against one another, brothers. He who speaks against a brother and judges his brother, speaks against the law and judges the law. But if you judge the law, you are not a doer of the law but a judge.
speaker: Narrator

text: Only one is the lawgiver, who is able to save and to destroy. But who are you to judge another?
speaker: Narrator

text: Come now, you who say, “Today or tomorrow let’s go into this city and spend a year there, trade, and make a profit.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Yet you don’t know what your life will be like tomorrow. For what is your life? For you are a vapor that appears for a little time and then vanishes away.
speaker: Narrator

text: For you ought to say, “If the Lord wills, we will both live, and do this or that.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But now you glory in your boasting. All such boasting is evil.
speaker: Narrator

text: To him therefore who knows to do good and doesn’t do it, to him it is sin.
speaker: Narrator

text: Come now, you rich, weep and howl for your miseries that are coming on you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Your riches are corrupted and your garments are moth-eaten.
speaker: Narrator

text: Your gold and your silver are corroded, and their corrosion will be for a testimony against you and will eat your flesh like fire. You have laid up your treasure in the last days.
speaker: Narrator

text: Behold, the wages of the laborers who mowed your fields, which you have kept back by fraud, cry out; and the cries of those who reaped have entered into the ears of the Lord of Armies.
speaker: Narrator

text: You have lived in luxury on the earth, and taken your pleasure. You have nourished your hearts as in a day of slaughter.
speaker: Narrator

text: You have condemned and you have murdered the righteous one. He doesn’t resist you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Be patient therefore, brothers, until the coming of the Lord. Behold, the farmer waits for the precious fruit of the earth, being patient over it, until it receives the early and late rain.
speaker: Narrator

text: You also be patient. Establish your hearts, for the coming of the Lord is at hand.
speaker: Narrator

text: Don’t grumble, brothers, against one another, so that you won’t be judged. Behold, the judge stands at the door.
speaker: Narrator

text: Take, brothers, for an example of suffering and of perseverance, the prophets who spoke in the name of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Behold, we call them blessed who endured. You have heard of the perseverance of Job and have seen the Lord in the outcome, and how the Lord is full of compassion and mercy.
speaker: Narrator

text: But above all things, my brothers, don’t swear—not by heaven, or by the earth, or by any other oath; but let your “yes” be “yes”, and your “no”, “no”, so that you don’t fall into hypocrisy.
speaker: Narrator

text: Is any among you suffering? Let him pray. Is any cheerful? Let him sing praises.
speaker: Narrator

text: Is any among you sick? Let him call for the elders of the assembly, and let them pray over him, anointing him with oil in the name of the Lord;
speaker: Narrator

text: and the prayer of faith will heal him who is sick, and the Lord will raise him up. If he has committed sins, he will be forgiven.
speaker: Narrator

text: Confess your sins to one another and pray for one another, that you may be healed. The insistent prayer of a righteous person is powerfully effective.
speaker: Narrator

text: Elijah was a man with a nature like ours, and he prayed earnestly that it might not rain, and it didn’t rain on the earth for three years and six months.
speaker: Narrator

text: He prayed again, and the sky gave rain, and the earth produced its fruit.
speaker: Narrator

text: Brothers, if any among you wanders from the truth and someone turns him back,
speaker: Narrator

text: let him know that he who turns a sinner from the error of his way will save a soul from death and will cover a multitude of sins.
speaker: Narrator
